Award.AwardTitle: RUI: The Function and Molecular Mechanisms of Novel RNAs in E. Coli

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
When they enter new environments, for example the human body or the water supply, bacteria quickly adapt by altering their gene expression patterns. This project will analyze a poorly understood class of regulators that may be important for such changes in gene expression in many if not most bacterial species. The research in this study will be divided into discrete projects for training undergraduate and Master's level students. The outcomes of the research will be conveyed to the community through specific outreach programs associated with the University of Colorado at Colorado Springs' Center for Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics Education. This Center is dedicated to promoting science education and hands-on experiences for economically disadvantaged and minority-serving Colorado public school districts.


Gene transcription is a highly regulated process, ensuring that only the genes necessary in a particular situation are expressed. Transcription was thought to occur exclusively at genes producing protein-coding mRNAs, ribosomal RNAs, and transfer RNAs. However, in the past decade, non-coding regulatory RNAs have emerged as a new class of transcribed genetic elements. More recently, large portions of the genome have been observed to be transcribed; this genome-wide transcription was termed pervasive transcription. Pervasive transcription was initially considered to be non-functional noise; however, there is now evidence suggesting that pervasive transcripts are functional. The objective of this project is to elucidate the function and molecular mechanisms of gene regulation by pervasive transcripts in the well-studied and genetically tractable model organism Escherichia coli. Traditional loss-of-function reverse genetic assays are challenging to perform on these RNAs because they overlap (or are complementary to) annotated genes. Therefore innovative methods to construct deletions of pervasive transcripts will be employed. These deletion strains will allow us to probe the role of pervasive RNAs in gene regulation and to dissect the molecular mechanisms of their regulation. Understanding the regulatory roles of pervasive transcripts, and the mechanisms they employ, in gene expression in E. coli will also offer insight into the gene regulation strategies of other bacteria, as well as eukaryotes, due to the widespread nature of pervasive transcription across all domains of life.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

Transcription initiation is a highly regulated step in gene regulation; several novel mechanisms of post-transcriptional gene regulation have been characterized in the last decade. RNAs have emerged as major regulators of gene expression in both bacteria and eukaryotes. Recently, advanced high-throughput sequencing techniques have uncovered a new type of RNA termed pervasive transcripts. Pervasive transcripts occur genome-wide and do not adhere to canonical gene boundaries. Transcription was thought to occur only at genes encoding proteins, ribosomal RNAs and transfer RNAs. Pervasive transcription has been reported in many different organisms across all domains of life and appears to yield a conserved class of RNAs. Despite the widespread occurrence of pervasive transcripts, little is known about their function and initially they were considered to be transcriptional noise.

Intellectual Merit

One of the most highly debated questions in the field of transcriptomics and regulatory RNA biology is the functionality of pervasive transcripts. Are these transcripts merely transcriptional noise or are they functional? Elucidating the functions and molecular mechanisms of gene regulation by pervasive transcripts will begin to answer this question. Moreover, understanding the molecular mechanisms that govern gene regulation in model organisms provides fundamental knowledge that can be applied to other systems. We have developed an innovative approach that allowed us to study pervasive transcipts. We have demonstrated that several pervasive transcripts are indeed functional and regulate gene expression. We have also uncovered several proteins that play a role in dsRNA formation or stabilization. These studies significantly advance the field of gene regulation and RNA biology by revealing the function and molecular mechanism of these newly identified RNAs. Our work resulted in twenty poster presentations and five seminar presentations at regional, national and international conferences and seminar series. Three manuscripts are in preparation for submission to peer-review journals.

Broader Impacts

The goals of this proposal are to elucidate the function and molecular mechanisms of pervasive transcription-dependent gene regulation in the model organism E. coli and integrate the research plan into discrete student projects for undergraduates and Master’s students. UCCS is located in the second largest city in Colorado and serves many non-traditional and first-generation students. Thirteen undergraduate student and two graduate students were trained in the Lybecker lab. These students made intellectual and technical contributions to the research projects. The research projects fostered and develop critical thinking skills as well as practical laboratory techniques, preparing the students for careers in science. Over half of these students came from underrepresented or disadvantaged populations. Of the ten students that have graduated 9 have remained in the STEM field. Three of the undergraduates went to medical school, two went to Ph.D programs, one went to a masters program. Several students obtained job in the industry including a research technician at the CDC.

Only a limited number of students were be able to participate in the research project in the Lybecker laboratory due to lab space and financial constraints, but Dr. Lybecker developed a new course and integrated her research into the course. This exposed over 30 students to original research. Finally, this research was brought to the community though specific outreach programs. Dr. Lybecker and students funded by this NSF award took part in a several community outreach programs. STEM for girls, Cool Science Carnival day and a half day laboratory experience for a middle school class. STEM for girls is focused on providing exposure of the STEM research to local middle school aged girls. In this outreach program, we used Drosophila, C. elegans and E. coli to teach students about Molecular Genetics and Neurobiology. In addition we had a workshop at the Cool Science Carnival Day. Cool Science Carnival Day is geared toward all ages of kids and adults. Our lab ran a 4-hour workshop on how genes are turned on. Participants worked with gfp expressing E. coli and learned about Genetics. Finally, the Lybecker Lab hosted several middle school science classes for a half-day workshop. Students extracted strawberry DNA and learned about genetics. These programs were very successful in engaging the students and helped expose the undergraduate and graduate students to teaching strategies in the classroom for various ages. Moreover, Dr. Lybecker hosted a two high school summer students in lab, whoc both went on to pursue degrees in STEM. Dr. Lybecker also presented at Science on Tap, a local initiative to bring Science to the public.
